entry.title: Boundless Previews Dublin Airport Upgrade for X-Plane 11 & 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Boundless has recently previewed the progress on their Dublin Airport (EIDW) upgrade for X-Plane 11 and 12, which adds the new runway (10L/28R), new fencing models, improved ground textures, and more. Dublin Airport is the 12th busiest airport in Europe, and the 1st in Ireland, with a yearly average of 30 million passengers. It hosts their flag carrier Aer Lingus, the low-cost carrier beast Ryanair, and TUI Airways, with a significant route network that encompasses most of Europe and some key cities in North America.Â According to BoundlessâÂ development reportÂ from late January, the update will bring full X-Plane 12 compatibility, new overhauled lighting (based on real-life reference imagery from 2023), the integration of the new runway, light tone updates on the Ryanair pier and Terminal 1, road traffic (XP12 only), airside traffic (XP12 only), new fence models, new ground textures, partial photorealistic textures based on 2023 imagery, FPS improvements, ortho updates to match the current state of the airport, general bug fixes, added barriers/fencing, new ground service equipment vehicles with 2023 liveries, road network improvements, better ortho and road network blending with default landclass, and the addition of road details. The developers even visited the airport to take reference pictures for the update, to warrant maximum acuity with the real-life counterpart. Thereâs no information on a potential release date yet, but they claim it should be out in a few days. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: UK2000 Scenery Releases Aurora Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. UK2000 Scenery has recently released their rendition of Chicago Aurora Municipal Airport (KARR) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, a public airport serving the city of Aurora, in Illinois. Itâs sometimes used as a reliever airport for OâHare and Midway, due to its proximity to Chicago (80 kilometers west).Â It houses the Air Classics Museum of Aviation, which includes a collection of aircraft, vehicles, uniforms, and other aviation memorabilia from the 30s to the current day. The aircraft collection includes a Republic P-47D Thunderbolt replica, a Bayerische Flugwerke Messerschmitt BF-109 replica, a North American Aviation RF-86F Sabre, a McDonnell Douglas TA-4J Skyhawk, a Republic Aviation F-105D Thunderchief, a North American T-39 Sabreliner, a McDonnell Douglas F-4B Phantom II, a Ling-Temco-Vought A-7E Corsair II, a Bell UH-1H Iroquois, a Curtiss P-40 WarHawk replica, and a North American Aviation P-51D Mustang Replica. As a curious fact, the Aurora Municipal Airport is one of the few airports in the United States where the FAA and IATA identifiers are not the same, because ARR was taken on the IATA by an airport in Argentina. Thus, it uses AUZ as its IATA code.Â The traffic figures sit at 76,650 aircraft operations between April 2021 and April 2022, averaging 210 per day, with 98% corresponding to general aviation, 2% to air taxi, and 1% to military and commercial, respectively.Â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport as it stands, with full-detail buildings, realistic ground markings, high-resolution ground imagery, custom night lighting, high-detail airport vehicles, full set of signs, fencing, vegetation, PBR materials, interior details and parallax internals, and optional static aircraft. Itâs available onÂ UK2000âs StoreÂ andÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $15.65 and $14.15, respectively. At least 24 MB of free disk space is required to install the product. entry.title: Cowan Simulation Updates 500E for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Cowan Simulation has recently issued the very first update to their rendition of the MD 500E, fixing issues with the flight model, adjusting the 3D model, and more. The MD Helicopters MD 500E is part of a family of light utility civilian and military helicopters, introduced in 1967 with the Hughes 500 (which was a civilian version of the OH-6A Cayuse/Loach), and developed over time into what it is now after Hughes was acquired in the 1980s by McDonnell Douglas Helicopters.Â The 500E variant is an executive version of the 500D with a recontoured nose, certified in 1982. Itâs powered by a Rolls-Royce Model 250-C20B turboshaft engine rated at 420 hp, with a maximum cruise speed of 135 knots and a range of 235 nautical miles at sea level, according to a 2022 chart. The update brings many improvements to the flight model based on customer feedback. The developer mentions it still flies with a slight low left skid, and they plan to work more with the flight model in the future. The trim ball was also improved, yet they say it's not quite optimized for helicopters when using the correct code. Adjustments were made to the air intake tube in the nose, along with other small details in the 3d model. The remainder of the changelog follows down below: The red emergency fuel cutoff valve code was fixed. There was a bug with wrong values. Now that should work properly. Pushed in is open and pulled out is closed. The ignition key needs to be on to run the starter now. Hopefully this does not trip anyone up.Â The two cabin light switches and the lighting attached was changed. Now one is red and one is white and they are not so bright so you can use them at night. All the other lighting was gone through and optimized. Added some ambient light from the green panel lights. Fixed the skid nav lights with flex. Added some occluders to the skids and new bear paws so the grass lays/smashes down when off pavement. The two buttons above the cabin light toggles are now tied to rotor wash and engine heat blur effects. Pushing them will disable either respectively. 15 new liveries were added to the package to make a total of 63 available. Thank you Chrigel Linder for your contribution to this project. â â The 500E is available onÂ Cowan Simâs StoreÂ andÂ SimMarketÂ for $32.99 and roughly $33.33, respectively. At least 2.30 GB of free disk space is required to install the product. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: Spinoza Releases Interlaken Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Spinoza has recently released their rendition of Interlaken Airport (LSMI) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, a former military airbase dating back to WW2. Built by the Swiss Army Military in 1940, it originally had two runways, with the first one made of concrete and 600m of total length, made operational in 1942. The second one, 900 meters long, was completed a year later. After the war, it was converted into a Jet Maintenance Base for the De Havilland Vampire, with an eventual runway expansion to accommodate the fighter (the original runway was extended to 920 meters), along with the construction of a control tower. Further lengthening happened in the following decades, where it ended up at 1656 meters. Commercial service took place for the first time in 1964, with Globe-Air flying from Interlaken to London thrice a week until 1967. The base was closed in 2003, now hosting REGA 10, a Swiss Air-Rescue service responsible for more than 1100 mountain rescue operations annually. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the former airport as it stands, with the military hangars, a 3D model of the Jungfrau Park, and the REGA 10 - Wilderswil base. Itâs available on SimMarket for roughly $14.11, requiring at least 223 MB of free disk space to install.Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: PMDG Releases Boeing 737-900 for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. PMDG has recently released their rendition of the Boeing 737-900 for Microsoft Flight Simulator, adding to the other - already released - three variants of their 737 lineup.Â The 737-900 is the longest 737 variant to date, with 42.11m of total length, seating up to 189 people in a high-density layout, or 177 on two-class, whilst keeping the same MTOW and fuel capacity as of the -800. It was first flown in 2001 with Alaska Airlines. The 737-900ER, on the other hand, can seat up to 220 passengers with a single-class configuration or 180 with two classes, along with an increased range (as implied by the name), around 3,280nm (the normal -900 only has 2,800nm). Due to its limited carrying capacity and range, the -900 was unsuccessful, with only 52 orders in total. The ER variant has accumulated over 500 orders recently. PMDGâs rendition features a fully customized system simulation for all major and minor aircraft system components, a highly sophisticated logical simulation of onboard information systems and aircraft management, a customized flight model with enhanced physics augmentation, rigid body physics for wing and tail surfaces, fully customized flight control systems, accurate resolution cockpit displays, interchangeable equipment options for cockpit instrumentation, numerous user-configurable options, native datalink simulation compatible with SimBrief, a driveable pushback tug, a custom sound package, a highly-detailed tridimensional cockpit, advanced animations, and a complete tutorial for 737 beginners.Â The developer has also listed some features that are to come in future updates, including the custom EFB, high-resolution cabin models and gear bay interiors for the entire 737 lineup, and Asobo-dependant updates such as the weather radar, which they mention as an example.Â The -900 ($49.99) and the rest of the lineup is available on theÂ PMDG ShopÂ for $34.99 (737-600) and $69.99 (737-700 and 737-800, individually).Â Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: iniBuilds Announces Bf108 Taifun for Microsoft Flight Simulator
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. iniBuilds has recently announced the second addition to their classic lineup for Microsoft Flight Simulator: the Bf108 Taifun, a single-engine sport aircraft developed by Bayerische Flugzeugwerke in the early 1930s, with 885 units built in total. The Taifun was designed to compete in the 4th Challenge International de Tourisme, the fourth and last International Tourist Plane Contest held by the FAI (FÃ©dÃ©ration aÃ©ronautique internationale), taking place in Warsaw, Poland. It was a major aviation event in pre-war Europe, held from 1929 to 1934. The prototype, then called M34, was powered by a 247 hp Hirth HM 8U V8 engine, did not win the competition, more so, was outperformed by many other aircraft, yet managed to impress with a low fuel consumption rate, good handling, and take-off/landing characteristics. The Bf108a variant took off for the first time in 1934, powered by three different engines: the original Hirth HM 8U, the Argus As 17B with 217 hp, and later units had a Siemens-Halske Sh 14 radial, with 158hp. The Bf108b was a revised version whose prototype had a Siemens-Halske Sh 14a radial, but the production model sported an Argus As 10C instead, delivering 237 hp, or the Argus AS 10E with 266 hp. iniBuildsâ rendition makes use of the latest CFD technology on all primary and control flight surfaces, as well as the propeller, and with specifically modeled unique characteristics of the real-life counterpart like the capability of landing as slow as 45 knots thanks to its leading edge slats. The inclusion of such details enables a realistic STOL performance. With the help of Microsoft Flight Simulatorâs modern fuel system, the developers managed to model an authentic fuel system that closely matches the real-world behavior of the Argus As10 engine. The airplane features interactable elements that range from foldable wings to doors and storage compartments, and many EFB-controlled features such as customizable rain covers, language, units, curtain visibility, etc. On that language note, they mention it will come with two sets of gauges and panel text, with German or English texts, and either metric or imperial units.
